results.title: Maze War
results.brief_description: Without Maze War, there wouldn’t be any first-person shooter videogames like Quake or Doom. Developed by Steve Cooley for NASA, Maze War featured forward, backwards, left and right movements, as well as first-person perspective.

constellations_other.name: Capturing first-person POV
constellations_other.description: A comparison of how videogames and feature films have used first person POV shots and sequences and how (for the latter) camera technology has impacted on this.

results.title: Mayurakshi Dam
results.creator_credit: N.K. Issar and Films Division, Government of India
results.brief_description: Mayurakshi Dam covering 3,500 acres in West Bengal utilises for irrigation and power, monsoon rain water once wasted. Government reclamation of 4,000 acres of waste land and establishment of model colonies with electricity and telephones enable relocation of displaced farmers, whose land, watered regularly, produced good harvests. West Bengal’s vast agricultural region looks forward to higher yields from newly vitalised land.

results.title: Mayola
results.brief_description: An abstract of colour changing forms made by photographing the reflections on a translucent screen of the sculptures of Nicholas Schoffer. Uses electronic music. Shown at the Brussels Experimental Festival.

results.title: Mayday mayday
results.creator_credit: Eric Fullilove, Austral Pacific Productions and B P Film for the Scout Association of Australia
results.brief_description: A film on adventure scouting showing how the movement has kept pace with changing times. It has updated its methods, increased the opportunities for fun and goo living for thousands of young people, but has still kept its ideals. Editor Paul Maxwell. Camera Phil Dority.

results.title: Maya of Ancient and Modern Yucatan
results.creator_credit: Arthur G. Evans, Guy Haselton and Bailey Film Productions
results.brief_description: The discoveries of archaeologists shows the high degree of civilization attained by the Maya people centuries ago. The Maya developed their own system of hieroglyphic writing and astronomers devised a calendar. A few Yucatecans still live in thatched huts, but most now live in modern cities. New industries are being researched and developed; transport systems improved; and greater emphasis placed on education. A new civilization is growing in this ancient land.

results.title: May wedding
results.creator_credit: Associated British-Pathe and British Information Services
results.brief_description: The wedding of H.R.H. Princess Margaret with Mr Antony Armstrong-Jones in Westminster Abbey on 6th May 1960. Records the enthusiasm and celebrations of the London crowds. Follows the Princess from her home at Clarence House, through the solemnity and splendour of the marriage ceremony, back with her bridegroom along the processional route to Buckingham Palace, and out from the Port of London in the Royal Yacht “Britannia” on the first stage of the Caribbean honeymoon. Commentary by Michael Redgrave.

results.title: Maximum security
results.creator_credit: Mark Stiles and Prisoners' Action Group
results.brief_description: This film describes life in the “intractable” section of a maximum security jail based on prisoners’ actual accounts. The “tracs” sections are notorious jails inside the jails, totally isolated from the outside world and beyond the reach of the law and of public scrutiny. A work funded through the Experimental Film and Television Fund.

results.title: Max's Christmas (K)
results.creator_credit: Paul R. Gagne, Michael Sporn, Michael Sporn Animation and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description: Ruby can’t get her little brother Max to go to sleep on Christmas Eve, and the fun begins as Max sneaks downstairs hoping to see Santa. Based on the book of the same title by Rosemary Wells. Voices: Jenny Agutter and Rex Robbins.

results.title: Maurice Sendak
results.creator_credit: Morton Schindel and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description: A visit to Maurice Sendak in his studio apartment, where he speaks of his favourite composers, expresses his admiration for painters and illustrators of the past, tells how these artists have influenced his own work, and traces the development of the book ‘Where the Wild Things Are’.

results.title: Matuta: an early morning fantasy
results.brief_description: Sunshine and bird calls herald the start of a new day. All is initially quiet as 3 sleepy occupants, one armed with a tuba, begin the day. Most of the action in this film takes place on a vacant block, as mysterious performers and exhibitionists appear before the bewildered three, bringing with them an explosion of music and sound. Cast includes William Freu, Martha Scott and Nickey Ribush.
